lexUnit.name: condone.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: accept or forgive (behaviour considered wrong or offensive)

sentence.text: I will reaffirm that I can not condone the use of cannabis , nor for that matter daily watching more than 5 hours of TV .
` The world might applaud your achievement but I doubt if it will condone your methods , " Nicholson said , taking his eyes from the bandaged man to look momentarily at Dexter .
Let us deal with the suggestion that it would be psychologically damaging to the country to show that the House condones homosexuality .
Labour 's shadow home secretary Tony Blair said : ` No one condones bogus applications for asylum .
It can not simply be assumed that a parent who is present at the injury of their child has condoned it .
They saw the school as condoning these teachers ' attitudes .
That many doctors condone this practice does not in itself indicate any moral justification .
Trade unionists can not condone the use of violence in this or any industrial dispute situation .
But Mitchell wo n't condone the taking of life and soon it seems both good guys and bad guys want him out of the way .
We do n't condone arson or violence , but many young people believe such actions are justified .

In the previous chapter it was emphasised that the authorities deliberately promoted and condoned violence , crime and racketeering in order to alienate both terrorist and legitimate political opponents of the government from their natural sympathisers .
It was daft of their business partner to say every Kray fan will want the game and even more incredible for him to add : ` Neither Reg or Ron would ever condone crime . "
Nor do they wish to condone the use of fighting or bullying by default , which means inaction .
` But no matter what he has done we ca n't condone anyone vandalising his house . "
Can it be that you condone his actions ?
Condoned truancy applied to some parents in disadvantaged areas for whom their children 's regular attendance at school came as a low priority as against other concerns .
While Miss Lidgett showed some appreciation of the woman 's circumstances , she was unable to condone her course of action .
` Last night you were threatening to ruin him if he hurt Maria Luisa again ; now you 're condoning their going away together . "
And corruption is condoned by powerful grandees in government and business .
At Arsenal FC we do not condone these sort of things .
Thai said , ` Intellectually , I do not condone terrorism . "
Truancy condoned by parents who ` authorise " the child 's absence was seen as a real problem .
Differential treatment and discrimination is condoned and made to appear normal .
Presidents , naturally , do not want to be seen to condone the taking of drugs ; the public temper is for stiff penalties and the locking up of offenders , not tender care .
Does the hon. Gentleman condone the borough of Southwark , which has £35 million-worth of rent arrears , for its failure to collect ?
